steps.tip:
How was this project initiated? Basic PM Slides
Who will be the sponsor?
Was this project type done before?
What metric or goal will this project affect?
Has the business problem been clearly stated?
Why are we doing this project?

Unerstanding a project's background establishes a solid foundation for the project.

At a minimum, it would be important to know who initiated the project, how the project was initiated, and why it was initiated. 

The more you know and understand about the background the better.  Has this project type been done before, if so what were the results? Are there any related successes that can be cloned or leveraged? What metric or goal will this project affect? Has the business problem been clearly stated?  The steps may change as your project evolves. Describing your project's background is the first title, or step in your project plan, (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

Gather project background information.  Describe why this project is needed, how it supports the organization’s goals, what problem it will solve, & what the key requirements are.  Pre-launch information is preliminary, gather what’s available, expanded & clarify the information as the project progresses.

 Projects solve or minimize problems & or create new opportunities.  Having a clear description of the problem or problems to be addressed will create focus.  Ensuring that all team members have a common understanding of the problem will enable project success.  If key individuals don't agree with the problem, they won't agree with the proposed solution.

​Gather project background information.  Describe why this project is needed, how it supports the organization’s goals, what problem it will solve, & what the key requirements are.  Pre-launch information is preliminary, gather what’s available, expanded & clarify the information as the project progresses.

 Brainstorm the presenting / initial idea to determine its scope & the viability of moving forward.  Ideas for projects & action items can come from many places.  They can be the result of senior management planning, customer requirements, employee suggestions, responses to daily problems, suggestions for leveraging new technology, etc., etc., etc.  Recognize that the presenting idea can change as you apply the project management process,  How ideas are handled are determined by the organization's culture.  An open & collaborative culture will welcome new ideas & have a way to process the idea while closed organizations may limit & even discourage new ideas.

​

The key question to automatically ask whenever a new idea surfaces is: What problem will this solve?  Recognize that how the problem is defined will determine the direction of the proposed solution.

​

Guidance Questions Small Project: 

    Where did the idea come from?
    Who's idea was it?
    Is this part of a broader plan?
    Does this idea support to organization's long term goals?
    Will the person who came up with the idea continue to be involved to help ensure success?
    Are there any key people who will disagree with the idea?
    Are there any major barriers to moving forward with the idea?
    Is this really a project, an action item, or someone's daily activity?
    What problem will this solve?
    Is this a new idea or has it been proposed before?
    If it was proposed before why did it come up again?
    Is now the right time to move forward with this idea?

Guidance Questions Medium Project:
    What do we need before we can start this work?
    Have we done this type of project before?
    Have we gathered & reviewed all available information from previous similar project(s).
    Have we assessed the results, comments. problems, & lessons learned from previous similar project(s).
    Review problems encountered & suggested solutions.
    Review lessons learned & recommendations.
    Does the company have a defined project commissioning process that senior management follows for business planning, project identification & vetting, & project monitoring?
    Does the company have a defined Project Management Process?​
    Was senior management involved in vetting and initiating this project?
    Does the company have a defined format for project plans?​
    Who is the project sponsor?
    What business strategy or initiative does it support?
    Who will be the project manager?
    What departments or stakeholders need to be represented on the core team?
    What’s the current business environment?
    What’s the organization’s current status, are there any major issues?
    Is the organization in crisis, business as usual, or growth?
    What’s the project’s priority?
    What’s the project’s background / history?
    What’s the proposed business problem?
    Are there defined business goals & objectives?
    What are the expected measurable business results?
    How will project success be determined?
    Are there any budget limits?
    Are there any scheduling issues?
    Will the project requirements & potential solution fit with the organization’s maturity & culture?


Guidance Questions: Brazonics
    What problem or problems need to be solved?
    What's the opportunity to be created?
    Is there more than one problem?
    Has this problem been previously addressed? 
    Why does this problem need to be solved?
    How will we know this task was completed?

Guidance Questions: Large Project
    What do we need before we can start this work?
    Who is the project sponsor?
    What business strategy or initiative does it support?
    Who will be the project manager?
    What departments or stakeholders need to be represented on the core team?
    What’s the current business environment?
    What’s the organization’s current status, are there any major issues?
    Is the organization in crisis, business as usual, or growth?
    What’s the project’s priority?
    What’s the project’s background / history?
    What’s the proposed business problem?
    Are there defined business goals & objectives?
    What are the expected measurable business results?
    How will project success be determined?
    Are there any budget limits?
    Are there any scheduling issues?
    Will the project requirements & potential solution fit with the organization’s maturity & culture?
    How will we know this deliverable was completed?

Record your findings along with any other appropriate information for this step in a shared document. Update the document with each subsequent step's information. This will be the team's working project plan (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

Record your findings in the project plan document, a template is available at www dot, continuous, business change, dot com, slash alexa, project plan, store the document so it can be accessed by the project teams, and track progress through each of your project's steps.

steps.tip:
Every Project requires a Project Manager who…..

    Takes the lead position in the project

    Facilitates the team process

    Collaborates with the team to create and execute the project plan

    Monitors and documents the progress of all project work

    Reports to the Sponsor on Project Process

    Facilitates & develops reporting updates to the cross-functional Project Management Steering Committee

 

The larger, the more complex, the more critical the project the more the project manager needs to be a planner, manager, negotiator, facilitator, & communicator & not a doer.

​

Project managers get things done.  The difference between effective and less effective project managers is whether the most important things get done.  While it would be great for all the identified work within a project to be completed on time, on budget, & per specifications; sometimes that’s just not feasible.  For that reason it’s important to identify & ensure that the most important or critical work is completed producing the most important or critical deliverables.

​

What’s absolutely necessary before the solution can go-live?

​​

How can project managers ensure predictable results?

    Follow a defined process

    Develop effective habits

    Ask probing open ended questions

    Influence required behavior change

​

Video clip of Peter Falk as Columbo, example of asking open ended probing questions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZiv8vkxMac 

    Acts as though he's confused & in a hurry

    Asks seemingly dumb questions

    No ego

    Makes it appear that the questions he asks occurred to him on the fly when in fact he planned each question prior to the meeting

    ​Included a balance between fact oriented questions & relationship oriented statements & questions

​

Identify the project manager, describe the involvement in previous projects, background in project management, time required for this project, & time availability to meet the requirements.

 

Guidance Questions:

    What do we need before we can start this work?

    Who will be the project manager?

    Has this person managed previous projects?

    Has this person been involved in this type of project?

    Is this person familiar with the project process & tools that will be required?

    Will the project manager require help & coaching from the sponsor?

    Will the project manager need help facilitating team meetings?

    Will the project manager need administrative support?

    Will the project manager need help with project communication?

    Will the project manager need help from technical experts?

    Will the project manager need help from financial experts?

    Will the project manager need help in dealing with difficult people?

    How will we know this deliverable has been completed?

​

- Understand Team member styles
- Sponsors will generally be Senior Managers who have ultimate responsibility for the successful completion of Business Initiatives….. 
- Sponsor Responsibilities Gives direction to the project
Obtains necessary resources including commitment of people & hours across the organization
Secures management agreements
Provides regular reports to management team
Is committed to ensuring results are achieved
Provides assistance / guidance to project manager
Provides political support
Creates project profile 
Sponsors will generally be Senior Managers who have ultimate responsibility for the successful completion of the project. The sponsor will usually be involved in launching the project. It is recommended that all projects have a sponsor.  The sponsor helps set the project’s direction, goals, & objectives, obtains necessary resources, commitments for participation across departments, secures management agreements, provides regular updates to the management team, provides assistance, guidance, & coaching to the project manager, & provides political support.

​

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?

    Who is the project sponsor?

    Is the sponsor a senior manager?

    Has the sponsor been a previous project sponsor?

    Will the sponsor need some coaching on being a project sponsor?

    Will the sponsor be involved in launching the project?

    What will be the sponsor’s involvement in the project?

    What meetings will the sponsor attend?

    What information will the sponsor require & how often?

    Will the sponsor help resolve cross-functional issues that may arise?

    How will we know this deliverable has been completed?

    How will we know this task was completed?

​

Every Project requires a Project Manager who….. 
Takes the lead position in the project
Facilitates the team process 
Collaborates with the team to create and execute the project plan
Monitors and documents the progress of the project
Reports to the Sponsor on Project Process


What Do PM Do?
1. Defines project goals, objectives, and requirements (with sponsor)
3. Defines the project scope, WBS, & Network Diagram (if required) 
5. Forms and leads the project team & publishes all plans
8. Recognizes and rewards accomplishments and successes
10. Monitors delivery against all plans and commitments
12. Identifies & mitigates risk
13. Controls changes
15. Chairs project team meetings
17. Involved in all project communication
19. Manages activities during each stage
2. Builds consensus and facilitates conflict resolution
4. Sets priorities and makes recommendations
6. Ensures completion of all deliverables
7. Minimize surprises
9. Provides direct communication with the sponsor
11. Coordinates and supports the project team
14. Focal point for issues, questions, and enhancements
16. Facilitates problem resolution
18. Maintains focus on behavior change required to produce the committed results
20. Rewards team performance

The Bottom Line:
Project managers get things done. 
 The difference between effective and less
   effective project managers is whether the most
   important things get done.

How can you ensure predictable results?
Follow a defined process
Develop effective habits
Ask questions

Team Member Responsibilities:
Understand, help develop, and support project direction, business results, & goals
Participate in planning, as needed
Accountable for completing tasks
Support each other and the project manager
Participate in problem resolution
Report status, uncover issues, & communicate
Keep your supervisor / manager informed of your work & time commitments 
Participate in all reviews and audits

Team Conflict Resolution

Team Operating Procedures:
Roles and responsibilities
Expectations
Meeting schedules
Meeting process
Automated & manual tools
Decision making & escalation process
Individual feedback
Performance management
Documentation
Team training and development
(Other)

Who Are the Stakeholders?


Brainstorm the presenting / initial idea to determine its scope & the viability of moving forward.  Ideas for projects & action items can come from many places.  They can be the result of senior management planning, customer requirements, employee suggestions, responses to daily problems, suggestions for leveraging new technology, etc., etc., etc.  Recognize that the presenting idea can change as you apply the project management process,  How ideas are handled are determined by the organization's culture.  An open & collaborative culture will welcome new ideas & have a way to process the idea while closed organizations may limit & even discourage new ideas.

​

The key question to automatically ask whenever a new idea surfaces is: What problem will this solve?  Recognize that how the problem is defined will determine the direction of the proposed solution.

​

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?

    Where did the idea come from?

    Who's idea was it?

    Is this part of a broader plan?

    Does this idea support to organization's long term goals?

    Will the person who came up with the idea continue to be involved to help ensure success?

    Are there any key people who will disagree with the idea?

    Are there any major barriers to moving forward with the idea?

    Is this really a project, an action item, or someone's daily activity?

    What problem will this solve?

    Is this a new idea or has it been proposed before?

    If it was proposed before why did it come up again?

    Is now the right time to move forward with this idea?



When projects are launched it’s common for the key players to have different views of the project’s purpose, problem to be solved, direction, and expected results.  The project manager’s role is to help move everyone to a common understanding & agreement.  The project process is designed to enable gaining consensus on the project’s elements.

 

Define the teams required & each team member’s role and specific responsibilities for the project.  Define how the project team will operate regarding meetings, decision making, escalation, performance management, communication, etc.  List key stakeholders and their role and responsibilities within the project.

 

Team Member Responsibilities:

    Understand, help develop, and support project direction, business results, & goals

    Participate in planning, as needed

    Accountable for completing tasks

    Support each other and the project manager

    Participate in problem resolution

    Report status, uncover issues, & communicate

    Keep your supervisor / manager informed of your work & time commitments

    Participate in all reviews and audits

​

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?

    How many & what kind of teams will be required?

    Who’s the project sponsor & what’s the sponsor’s involvement in the project?

    Who are key project stakeholders & what’s their involvement in the project?

    Who’s the project manager & team leader for each team or sub-team?

    What departments need to be represented on the project core team?

    Who are the core team members & what are their roles & responsibilities?

    What skills are required on the project core team?

    How often & when will project team meetings be held?

    Who will be required to participate in project team meetings?

    How will project team decisions be made?

    How will project team meetings be managed?

    What’s the escalation process?

    How will project team performance issues be handled?

    Who will record & track the schedule, action items & issues?

    Who will record assumptions?

    What automated tools will be used?

    Do team members need any training?

    How will we know this deliverable was completed?


Describe how the project will be launched, who will be involved in launching it, and what information will be made available or has been made available for the launch.

 

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?

    How will the project be launched?

    Will it be a formal or informal launch?

    Is this a standalone project or is it part of a larger program or business initiative?

    Who will be involved in launching the project?

    Who was involved in launching the project?

    What information will be provided to the project leader and project team?

    What information was provided to the project leader and project team?

    Is there any additional information that the team believes they need?

    How will we know this deliverable was completed?

​
​

Large Project
Describe how the project will be launched, who will be involved in launching it, and what information will be made available or has been made available for the launch.
 

Guidance Questions: 
    What do we need before we can start this work?
    How will the project be launched?
    Will it be a formal or informal launch?
    Is this a standalone project or is it part of a larger program or business initiative?
    Who will be involved in launching the project?
    Who was involved in launching the project?
    What information will be provided to the project leader and project team?
    What information was provided to the project leader and project team?
    Is there any additional information that the team believes they need?
    How will we know this deliverable was completed?

Step two, launch the project, and establish the teams detail. Verify you have all required background information and are ready to launch the project. Projects started in haste without adequate information typically become problem projects. Describe how the project will be launched. Define the teams, at a minimum you'll have a core team, with the members that will be actively involved throughout the entire project. Many projects, also require extended teams, that work on specific portions of the project. Your project team can be your biggest asset, it can also be your biggest risk. Take the time to get to know every team member, and develop effective relationships. If you would like more detail for this step, say Project Launch or Teams. When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, Step Three. (Changed 8-02-19, Not Uploaded)

questions.question: 1. Is someone assigned to ensure this step in completed?
2. Do you have what you need before you can start this step?
3. Are there any tasks that need to be completed before this step can start?
4. Has work on this step started?
5. Do you have a plan for launching the project?
6. Do you know how many teams will be required?
7. Do you know the departments or functions that need to be represented on the core team?
8. Have the team members been identified and confirmed?
9. Have you identified how often, how, and where the teams will meet?
10. Have you identified a general estimate of the time required for each team member?
11. Has team member responsibilities been assigned?
12. Do any of the teams or individual members need specific training?
13. Have team norms been established?
14. Have team operating procedures been defined?
15. Have you determined the completion criteria for this step?
16. Has this step been completed?

steps.tip:
Projects are never done for their own purpose, they are always part of or support a higher goal, or objective.  Describe the business strategies or initiatives that this project supports and how it supports them.

​Describe the business problem & opportunity the project is intended to address.  Include a description of any market and / or internal conditions and dynamics that might affect consideration of the project, as well as any prior attempts to address the underlying business problem.  The described problem determines your approach.

What’s the business problem / opportunity
“If we don’t agree on the problem we won’t agree on the solution.”
Define proposed solution
Develop goals & objectives
Define measurable business results
Identify proposed deliverables
Record & validate assumptions
(Define & share the project process

 Describe what the project is expected to produce, create, or do. Describe the future state, what it will look and feel like, what will be in place.  Create goals and or objectives that are measurable.

 Define and quantify the tangible business results that this project is expected to produce (example; increased revenue, decreased expenses, increased market share, increased customer satisfaction, etc.) 

Define the key factors that will be used to determine and measure project success from the users or customer’s perspective and describe what the organization stands to gain (or not lose) by implementing the project.

Project Launch: Describe how the project will be launched, who will be involved in launching it, and what information will be made available or has been made available for the launch.

Project Teams: Define the teams required & each team member’s role and specific responsibilities for the project.  Define how the project team will operate regarding meetings, decision making, escalation, performance management, communication, etc.  List key stakeholders and their role and responsibilities within the project.

Business Problem & Opportunity: Describe the business problem & opportunity the project is intended to address.  Include a description of any market and / or internal conditions and dynamics that might affect consideration of the project, as well as any prior attempts to address the underlying business problem.  The described problem determines your approach.

Goals & Objectives: Describe what the project is expected to produce, create, or do. Describe the future state, what it will look and feel like, what will be in place.  Create goals and or objectives that are measurable

Measurable Business Results: Define and quantify the tangible business results that this project is expected to produce (example; increased revenue, decreased expenses, increased market share, increased customer satisfaction, etc.) 

Critical Success Factors: Define the key factors that will be used to determine and measure project success from the user's or customer’s perspective and describe what the organization stands to gain (or not lose) by implementing the project.

Brainstorm the presenting / initial idea to determine its scope & the viability of moving forward.  Ideas for projects & action items can come from many places.  They can be the result of senior management planning, customer requirements, employee suggestions, responses to daily problems, suggestions for leveraging new technology, etc., etc., etc.  Recognize that the presenting idea can change as you apply the project management process,  How ideas are handled are determined by the organization's culture.  An open & collaborative culture will welcome new ideas & have a way to process the idea while closed organizations may limit & even discourage new ideas.

​Describe why this project is needed, how it supports the organization’s goals, what problem it will solve, & what the key requirements are.  This is typically preliminary information & may change as you apply the steps in the project management process, gather what’s available, expand & clarify the information as the project progresses.

​

Gather background information, perform research, brainstorm to understand & validate the need for the project.

​

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?​

    Have we done this type of project before?

    Have we gathered & reviewed all available information from previous similar project(s).

    Have we assessed the results, comments. problems, & lessons learned from previous similar project(s).

    Review problems encountered & suggested solutions.

    Review lessons learned & recommendations.

    Was senior management involved in vetting and initiating this project?

    Is this project part of a broader initiative?

    What's the potential scope of this project?

    What's the potential duration of this project?

    Does the company have a defined format for project plans?​

    Who is the project sponsor?

    What business strategy or initiative does it support?

    Do we have the capacity to do this project now?

    Do we have the resources to do this project now?

    Is this a high, medium, or low priority project?

    Does this project have any unique schedule requirements?

    Does this project have any unique budget requirements?

    Who will be the project manager?

    What departments or stakeholders need to be represented on the core team?

    What’s the current business environment?

    Is the organization in crisis, business as usual, or growth?

    What’s the project’s priority?

    What’s the proposed business problem?

    Are there defined business goals & objectives?

    What are the expected measurable business results?

    How will project success be determined?

    Are there any budget limits?

    Are there any scheduling issues?


The key question to automatically ask whenever a new idea surfaces is: What problem will this solve?  Recognize that how the problem is defined will determine the direction of the proposed solution.

​

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?

    Where did the idea come from?

    Who's idea was it?

    Is this part of a broader plan?

    Does this idea support to organization's long term goals?

    Will the person who came up with the idea continue to be involved to help ensure success?

    Are there any key people who will disagree with the idea?

    Are there any major barriers to moving forward with the idea?

    Is this really a project, an action item, or someone's daily activity?

    What problem will this solve?

    Is this a new idea or has it been proposed before?

    If it was proposed before why did it come up again?

    Is now the right time to move forward with this idea?

​

Guidance Questions

Project Launch:

    What do we need before we can start this work?
    How will the project be launched?
    Will it be a formal or informal launch?
    Is this a standalone project or is it part of a larger program or business initiative?
    Who will be involved in launching the project?
    Who was involved in launching the project?
    What information will be provided to the project leader and project team?
    What information was provided to the project leader and project team?
    Is there any additional information that the team believes they need?

Project Teams:

    How many & what kind of teams will be required?
    Who’s the project sponsor & what’s the sponsor’s involvement in the project?
    Who are key project stakeholders & what’s their involvement in the project?
    Who’s the project manager & team leader for each team or sub-team?
    What departments need to be represented on the project core team?
    Who are the core team members & what are their roles & responsibilities?
    What skills are required on the project core team?
    How often & when will project team meetings be held?
    Who will be required to participate in project team meetings?
    How will project team decisions be made?
    How will project team meetings be managed?
    What’s the escalation process?
    How will project team performance issues be handled?
    Who will record & track the schedule, action items & issues?
    Who will record assumptions?
    What automated tools will be used?
    Do team members need any training?

Business Problem & Opportunity:
    What’s been the history?
    Why are we doing this project?
    What’s the external need to do the project?
    What’s the internal need to do the project?
    How will this project help?
    What will it produce that we can build on?
    Have there been previous attempts at doing a similar project?
    What were the results & learnings of any previous attempts?

Goals & Objectives:
    What is the proposed business solution?
    What are the goals of the project?
    What are the project objectives?
    What will the project produce?
    Are the goals and or objectives specific?
    Are the goals and or objectives measurable?
    Are the goals and or objectives attainable?
    Are the goals and or objectives realistic?
    Are the goals and or objectives time based?

Measurable Business Results:
    What business metrics will be impacted or affected?
    If the project is successful, what are the business results that will be realized?
    How will the expected results be monitored and tracked?
    What will happen if the results are not as expected?
    Are there any new metrics that need to be established or tracked?
    What will the intangible results or by-products be?

Critical Success Factors:

    What will determine project success?
    How will project success me measured?
    Why should senior management approve this project?
    What will the people or impacted groups experience as benefits?
    What will the intangible results or by-products be?
    How will we know this deliverable was completed?

Step three, project purpose summary. At a minimum the project's purpose will include the problem to be solved, proposed solution, goals, and expected measurable results. (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

Step three, project purpose detail, update the project plan document with your Project's Purpose. At a minimum the project's purpose will include the problem to be solved, proposed solution, goals, expected measurable results, and the the process steps for the remainder of this project. Gaining agreement on the problem to be solved is the foundation for any project. If we don't agree on the problem, we won't agree on the solution. If you would like more detail for this step, say Project Purpose. When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, step four. (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

steps.tip:
Create the initial schedule in an appropriate tool; Excel, Smartsheet, other, for the project based on the WBS ensuring all work has been identified & accounted for including the project management work.  Using the WBS and schedule identify & describe the project’s milestones.

​

Guidance Questions: 
    What do we need before we can start this work?
    Has the assigned resource for each task verified the start & completion?
    What are the key milestones?
    How will personnel assignments impact cost?
    Has enough float been built into the schedule?
    What’s the impact If the project completion date is missed?
    How will we know this deliverable was completed?

Create the initial schedule in an appropriate tool; Excel, Smartsheet, other, for the project based on the WBS ensuring all work has been identified & accounted for including the project management work.  Using the WBS and schedule identify & describe the project’s milestones.  When you have multiple tasks or work packages under a particular deliverable or sub-deliverable the task with the earliest start date is the start for the deliverable & the latest finish date is the deliverables finish date.

​

Guidance Questions: 
    What do we need before we can start this work?
    Has the assigned resource for each task verified the start & completion?
    What are the key milestones?
    How will personnel assignments impact cost?
    Has enough float been built into the schedule?
    What’s the impact If the project completion date is missed?
    How will we know this deliverable was completed?


Schedule:

Create the initial schedule in an appropriate tool; Excel, Smartsheet, other, for the project based on the WBS ensuring all work has been identified & accounted for including the project management work.  Using the WBS and schedule identify & describe the project’s milestones.  If a specific schedule must be met constantly monitor commitment dates.  

Step four, preliminary schedule summary, Begin creating the preliminary project schedule. Select a scheduling tool that's appropriate for your project. The preliminary schedule should follow the steps defined in the project process you intend to use. If you would like more detail for this step, say detail, When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, Step Five. (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

Step Four, preliminary schedule detail, Begin creating the preliminary project schedule. Projects have a beginning and an end, and are therefore date or schedule driven. Select a scheduling tool that's appropriate for your project. The preliminary schedule should follow the steps defined in the project process you intend to use. Focus on specific dates for the first six steps. Include a proposed schedule for the rest of the expected steps. At this point in your project consider the schedule as preliminary, or a wish, until you have accomplished the first six steps. If you would like more detail for this step, say Preliminary Schedule, When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, Step Five. (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

questions.question: 1. Is someone assigned to ensure this step in completed?
2. Do you have what you need before you can start this step?
3. Are there any tasks that need to be completed before this step can start?
4. Has work on this step started?
5. Have you selected an appropriate scheduling tool?
6. Do any of the team members need training on the scheduling tool?
7. Has the preliminary schedule been developed?
8. Has the preliminary schedule been shared?
9. Has the schedule update process been defined?
10. Have you determined the completion criteria for this step?
11. Has this step been completed?

steps.tip:
Step five, project deliverables summary, Projects produce, create, and implement deliverables. A deliverable is a thing, and should sound like a noun. We create deliverables by doing work, or tasks, Tasks start with a verb. Develop, design, initiate, etc, The most effective way to identify project deliverables, and the required tasks, is to facilitate the core team in creating a graphical Work Breakdown Structure W B S, using post-it notes. The tasks to produce a deliverable have a beginning and an end, rolling up the dates for all the project's deliverables becomes the project's estimated schedule. Completion criteria for this step is to have identified the project's deliverables, and the key tasks for producing each deliverable. If you would like more detail for this step, say Project Deliverables, When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, Step Six. (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

Create a graphical view or hierarchical outline of what the project will deliver.  Develop the project Work Breakdown Structure by identifying the project’s deliverables, sub-deliverables, tasks & or work packages.  View the WBS video

 

Guidance Questions: 
    What do we need before we can start this work?
    What things need to be created or changed?
    What things are needed to accomplish the objectives & measurable results?
    What behaviors need to be influenced or changed?
    What things need to be created to influence the required behaviors?
    What are the Deliverables, Sub-deliverables, & Tasks / Work Packages?
    Will anything in the current culture need to change to ensure project success?
    How will we know this deliverable was completed?


​
How to Create the WBS

Describe the process that will be used to approve the project plan.  List who will be involved and if it will require a formal or informal approval.  Describe who will need to be involved in reviewing & approving on-going project progress, results, and changes.  Define how issues that cannot be resolved / decided by the project team will be escalated & how the project sponsor is expected to participate in removing barriers. 

 

Guidance Questions: 

    What do we need before we can start this work?
    What is the Definition Phase approval process for this project?
    Who will be involved in reviewing and approving the project’s Definition Phase?
    Are any pre-approvals required?
    Are there any individuals or groups that need to preview specific information?
    What information will need to be prepared in order to gain approval?
    Has the approval process been built into the schedule and budget?
    How will the sponsor be involved in the project approvals?
    Who will be involved in the implementation phase approvals?
    How will issues or change requests be escalated?
    How will changes to the project be handled and approved?
    How will we know this task was completed?

Step six, preliminary approval summary. best practice would be to share and gain agreement or approval for the project work up to this point. All business projects should have gone through these six steps. Depending on the scope of the project, and organizational needs, the approval may be formal or informal, in person or virtual. Compile the project information appropriate for the audience. Provide summary information for management and general stakeholders, and detailed for core team members. If you would like more detail for this step, say Preliminary Approval, When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, Step Seven. (Changed 7-30-19, Not Uploaded)

steps.tip:
Identify the departments and / or groups most impacted by the project and whose requirements will need to be considered and understood in order to ensure project success.  The elements to discuss & gather from each group include their view of the project’s goals, their needs & wants, current business state, key assumptions, technology requirements, quality requirements & organizational considerations. 

 

Guidance Questions: 
    What do we need before we can start working on this item?
    What departments will be most impacted by the project?
    Which department’s requirements will significantly drive the project’s direction?
    What are each key group’s goals & objectives for the project?
    How involved does each key group intend to be in the project?
    How involved does each key group need to be in the project?
    What are the key group’s needs?
    What are the key group’s wants?
    What’s the key group’s current state?
    What are their assumptions?
    Why do they believe that…?
    It appears that they are assuming…?
    What are the assumptions that appear to be driving resistance within the groups?
    What are the assumptions that appear to be driving support within the groups?
    What’s the risk of proceeding with certain assumptions?
    What are the group’s requirements and specifications?
    How will we assess and validate the requirements and specifications?
    What are the technology requirements and specifications?
    How will we assess and validate the technology requirements and specifications?
    What are the quality / performance requirements?
    How will we assess and validate the quality requirements and specifications?
    How will we know this item has been completed?
​

Step seven, Additional Requirements, Depending on the project, initial requirements have already been shared during the first six steps. Additional requirements can come from multiple groups, such as customers, management, project sponsor, stakeholders, users of the intended solution, groups impacted by the problem and proposed solution, regulators, citizens, and local, state, and federal government. Identify the groups that will be providing the summary and detailed requirements for your project. Consider meeting with representatives from the key groups, facilitate a session for gathering the following information, group's goals and objective for the project, their needs and wants, their current state, key assumptions, solution requirements, technology requirements, quality requirements, and organizational considerations.  Ask open ended questions, document the requirements, review each requirement, decide which ones will be met, provide feedback to the groups explaining the results of the meetings, decisions and reasons for the actions to be taken. If you would like more detail for this step, say Project Requirements, When you have sufficient information, continue to the next step by saying, Step Eight.
